titleStmt.title: An Answer
To a late scandalous Poem, wherein
the Author most audaciously presumes

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: By Dennis Nephelee, chief
Cap of Howth.
Presumptuous Poet, could you dare
A Cloud with Woman kind compare?
Strange pride and insolence you shew,
Inferior mortals there below.
And, is our thunder in your earson facing verso against lines 5-8:ins·alternative·As,·above So grating, or ins·alternative·as·above·so loud as theirs?
We onely send our Thunder out,

insIn hopes To make you Mortals more devoutdelA thousandth part sodel·So terrible, so loud·ins·So grating or so·loud as theirsdelFor when weins·caret·then·del·We onely ?never·send our Thunder out,delIt servesins·caret·then·del·Except to make you ins then delmortals·more devout;
And, is not femal clattring worse,
Which drives you not to pray, but cursedel?Wh·We hardly thunder thrice a year: 4 lines scored in right margin
The bolt discharg'd, the sky grows clear;
But, ev'ry sublunary dowdy
The more she scolds, the more she's cloudy.How use overufu overlll were a womans thunder
If she like us would burst asunder!Yet, though her spouse hath often curst her,
And, whisp'ring wisht, the Devil burst her,faint endpunct due to water damage
For hourly thundring in hisoverer face,
She ne'r was found ins alternativeknown to burst a lace.Some Criticks may object perhaps,
That Clouds are blam'd for giving Claps:
But, what alas! are Claps aetherial
Compar'd for mischief, to Venereal?
Can Clouds give buboes, ulcers, blotches?
Or, from your noses dig out notches?
We leave the body sweet and sound,
May kill perhaps, but never wound.You know, a cloudy sky bespeaks
Fair weather when the morning breaks.
But, women in a cloudy plight
Foretell a storm to last till night.When Syrius o'er the welkin rages,
Our kindly help his fire assuagesA cooling Cloud the sun eclypses,
Else you might all be tann'd like Gypsyes.
But, Woman is a curst inflamer;
No parish ducking-stool can tame her,
To kindle strife Dame Nature taught her,
Like fire-works, she can burn in water.For Fickleness how durst you blame us?
Who, for our Steddyness are famous
You men would be in wofull pickle4 lines scored in left margin
If Clouds ins caretwere but like Femals fickle;When e'er we pleas'd to drop a show'r
How would the Beaux and Toupees scour!You'll see a Cloud in gentle weather
Keep the same face an hour together;
While Women, if it could be reckon'd
Change ev'ry feature ev'ry Second.Observe our visage in a morning;
Of foul and fair we give you warning;
But, can you guess from Womens air
One minute whether foul or fair?Go read in antient books enroll'd
What honors we possesst of old.
To disappoint Ixion's rape
Iove dresst a Cloud in Iuno's shape,
Which when he had enjoy'd, he swore,
No Goddess could have pleas'd him more.
No diff'rence could he find between
His Cloud, and Iove's imperiall Queen.
This Cloud produc'd a race of Centaurs
Fam'd for a thousand bold adventures
From us descended ab origine,
By learned authors call'd Nubigenae.
But say, what earthly nymph do you know,
So beautifull to pass for Iuno?Before AEneas durst aspire
To court her Majesty of Tyre
His mother begg'd of us to dr overiess him
That Dido smitten, might ins caretmore caress him
A Coat we gave him dy'd in grain
A flaxen wig, and clouded cane,
With which he made at tearing show:
And Dido quickly smoak't the Beau.Among your femals make inquiryes:
What nymph on earth so fair as Iris?
With heav'nly beauty so endow'd;
And yet her father is a Cloud:
We dresst her in a gold Brocade,
To rigg her out for Iuno's mayd.Tis known, that Socrates the wise
Ador'd the Clouds as Deityes.
To us he made his dayly pray'rs,
As Aristophanes declares;
From Iupiter took all dominion,
And dy'd defending his opinion.
By his authority tis plain,You worship other Gods in vain
And from your own experience know
We govern all things there below.
You follow where we please to guide:
O'er all your passions we preside:
Can raise them up, or sink them down,
As we think fit to smile or frown;
And, just as we dispose your brain,
Are witty, dull, rejoyce, complain.Compare us then to femal race!
We, to whom all the Gods give place.
They have no claim to Your allegiance
Because they live in lower regions
You find, the Gods in Homer dwell
In seas and Woods, or low as hell
Ev'n Iove, and Mercury his pimp
No higher climb than mount Olymp
(Who makes you think the Clouds he pierces:
He pierce the Clouds! he kiss our a────s)
While we, o'er Tenariffa plac't,
Are lofty'r by a mile at least.
And, when Apollo struts on Pindus,
We see him from our kitchin windows,
Or, to Parnassus looking down,
Can p────s upon his lawrel crown.Fate never form'd the Gods to flye
Theinsymust be carryed through the sky
When Iove would some fair nymph inveigle
He comes full gallop on his eagle:
Though Venus be as light as air,
She must have doves to draw her chair:
Though insMercury makes use of Wings
With which from earth to heav'n he springs;
He never honestly came by 'em,
And, e'er he flyes is forc'd to tye em.
Apollo stirs not out of dore
Without his taudry coach and four:
And, jealous Iuno, ever snarling,
Is drawn by peacocks in her BerlinBut, we can fly whene'er we please
O'er cityes, rivers, hills, and Seas,
From East to west the world we roam,
And, in all clymats are at home:
Provide you duly as we go
With sun-shine, rain, and hail, and snow.Tis but by our peculiar grace
That Phebus ever shows his face:
For when we please, we open wide
Our curtains blue on either side;
You see how sawcily he shows
His carrot locks, and fiery nose;
And gives himself a haughty air,
As if he made the weather fair.Tis sung; wherever Celia tread overss,
The Vi'lets ope their purple heads,
The Roses blow, the Cowslip springs:
Tis sung. But we know better things.
Tis true; a Woman on her mettle
Will often p────s upon a nettle;Yet, though we grant she makes it wetter,
The nettle never thrives the better.
But we by gentle April showers
Produce in May the sweetest flowrs.Your Poets Chloe's beauty heightning
Compare her radiant eyes to Lightning;
And yet, I hope 't will be allow'd,
No Lightning comes but from a Cloud.
However, we have too much sense
At Poets flights to take offence:
Nor can Hyperbole's demean us,
What Drabs have been compar'd to Venus?
Observe the case: I state it thus:ins alternativeYou may compare your Trull aboveThough Chloe you compare to us;But think how damnably you err
When you compare us Clouds to her:
From whence you draw such bold conclusions;
But, Poets love profane allusions.
And, if you now so little spare us,
Who knows how soon you compare us
To To Chartres, Walpole, or a King,
If once we let you have your Swing.
Such wicked insolence appears
Offensive to all pious ears.
To flatter Woman by a Metapher!
What profit could You hope to get of her
And, for her sake turn base detractor
Against your greatest benefactor.But, we shall keep revenge in store
If ever you provoke us more.
For since we knew you walk a-foot,
We'll soundly drench your frize Sur-toudamaged
Or may inswe never thunder throw,
Nor souse to death a Birth-day Beau.
We own, Your verses verses are melodious.
But such Comparisons are odious.617M339H
